TopicTitle: Is Kerbal Space Program 2 a Simple Rockets 2 copy or....

Articles.Content:
The title says it all. 

Basically, I have seen a previous post where the flight UI of the sequel of Kerbal Space Program (which is KSP 2)was shown. It looked quite similar to SR 2.

Please write your opinion down below.

Edited August 25, 2019 by Nigel J. Cardozo

I mean, it's darker and more minimalist than KSP 1, which is closer to SR 2, but I can't call it a copy.  I'm not super familiar with SR2 myself, but it looks like there's more data in KSP2's screen, and ultimately you're going to see a lot of the same features because that's how flight instruments work: you need velocity, heading, etc so of course there will be similarities, but calling it a copy is a bit too far IMO.

SR 2 is built with the intention of moving to a mobile platform. Hence, the PC release is where all the bugs are hammered out. Most likely, to optimise for mobile devices, the controls are built with touchscreens in mind, and to save on parts, models, textures and data, everything is procedural.
Well designed UIs are probably going to look similar. It is rocketry after all.
It's a genre.  A genre with very few games, but a genre none the less.  Simple Rockets isn't a copy of Kerbal Space Program, and KSP2 isn't a copy of SR2.

3 minutes ago, Nigel J. Cardozo said:

Oh....

And SR2 does not have small little green beings for you to, er, blow up I mean do science.

Pick one:

  2. No, they're both copies of KSP.

Edited August 24, 2019 by Nigel J. Cardozo
As this is more about SR than KSP it seems, moving it to the lounge.

they are all just orbiter clones. which in of itself is a clone of lunar lander which in turn harks back to asteriods. 

its like trying to find the roots of something like black metal. norway claims that they invented it, but they were copying a lot of extreme metal bands from the '86 explosion, but then celtic frost beat them all by a year. then of course they are all copying bathory which got started in '83. and then you got venom which coined the name of the genre in '82. they are all exploring themes initiated by black sabbath in the 70s. and of course sonically the sound comes from the acid rock band cromagnon, with their song caledonia. dig even deeper and your listening to the ring cycle and the opera faust which was the first use of what we would call death vocals that i could find. idk what people before the mid 19th century did for their black metal fix. but im sure if i jumped in that rabbit hole id would find another one at the bottom.

Edited August 24, 2019 by Nuke

The big difference between KSP and Simple Rockets line of game is the presence (and respectively, lack of) soft-joint physics. Soft-joint physics allow your craft to bend at the part joints from external stresses.

But is soft-joint physics a good idea or not ? I guess I'll leave that question to each individual.
It is ok only for some situations
